On the best possible exponent for the error term in the lattice point counting problem on the first Heisenberg group

Yoav A. Gath
Faculty of Mathematics
Technion, Israel Institute Of Technology

1 Introduction, notation and statement of results

1.1 General counting principles

Counting lattice points in Euclidean space. Given a region â„¬âŠ‚â„nâ„¬superscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathcal{B}\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}, the problem of estimating the number of integral points in large homothetic regions |â„¤nâˆ©tâ€‹â„¬|superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„¬|\mathbb{Z}^{n}\cap t\mathcal{B}| has a long history which can be traced back to Gauss and Dirichlet. Under suitable assumptions on â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}, we expect the quantity |â„¤nâˆ©tâ€‹â„¬|superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„¬|\mathbb{Z}^{n}\cap t\mathcal{B}| to be well approximated by Î»â€‹(tâ€‹â„¬)ğœ†ğ‘¡â„¬\lambda(t\mathcal{B}) == vol(tâ„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}), and we measure the resulting discrepancy arising from this approximation by analyzing the error term â„°â€‹(t)=|â„¤nâˆ©tâ€‹â„¬|âˆ’Î»â€‹(tâ€‹â„¬)â„°ğ‘¡superscriptâ„¤ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„¬ğœ†ğ‘¡â„¬\mathcal{E}(t)=|\mathbb{Z}^{n}\cap t\mathcal{B}|-\lambda(t\mathcal{B}). To get a handle on the error term, we introduce the notion of an admissible exponent. Say Î±ğ›¼\alpha is an admissible exponent if one has the estimate |â„°â€‹(t)|â‰ªÏµ(Î»â€‹(tâ€‹â„¬))Î±+Ïµsubscriptmuch-less-thanitalic-Ïµâ„°ğ‘¡superscriptğœ†ğ‘¡â„¬ğ›¼italic-Ïµ\big{|}\mathcal{E}(t)\big{|}\ll_{\epsilon}(\lambda(t\mathcal{B}))^{\alpha+\epsilon} for any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0, as tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘¡t\to\infty. Setting Îº=infÎ±ğœ…subscriptinfimumğ›¼\kappa=\inf_{\alpha}, where the infimum is taken over all admissible exponents, the (Euclidean) lattice point counting problem is that of establishing an asymptotic estimate of the form

|â„¤nâˆ©tâ€‹â„¬|=Î»â€‹(tâ€‹â„¬)+ğ’ªÏµâ€‹(Î»â€‹(tâ€‹â„¬))Îº+Ïµsuperscriptâ„¤ğ‘›ğ‘¡â„¬ğœ†ğ‘¡â„¬subscriptğ’ªitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğœ†ğ‘¡â„¬ğœ…italic-Ïµ|\mathbb{Z}^{n}\cap t\mathcal{B}|=\lambda(t\mathcal{B})+\mathcal{O}_{\epsilon}(\lambda(t\mathcal{B}))^{\kappa+\epsilon} (1.1)

For any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0.

Below we list three motivating examples which have played an important role in the development of this subject.
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Euclidean balls. In â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2} one has Îºâ‰¤131416ğœ…131416\kappa\leq\frac{131}{416} due to Huxley [12], while the conjectured value is Îº=14ğœ…14\kappa=\frac{1}{4}. In â„3superscriptâ„3\mathbb{R}^{3} one has Îºâ‰¤2148ğœ…2148\kappa\leq\frac{21}{48} due to Heath-Brown [9], while the conjectured value is Îº=13ğœ…13\kappa=\frac{1}{3}. For nâ‰¥4ğ‘›4n\geq 4, the value of Îºğœ…\kappa has been obtained, and its value is Îº=1âˆ’2nğœ…12ğ‘›\kappa=1-\frac{2}{n}. For more details we refer the reader to [19].
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Euclidean dilates of smooth compact convex bodies in â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n} whose boundary surface has everywhere non-vanishing Gaussian curvature. These include amongst others, ellipsoids and other bodies of revolution, and for the relevant results on the error estimates we refer the reader to [11], [10], [1] and [13].
âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Euclidean dilates of bodies in â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n} whose boundary surface contains points of vanishing Gaussian curvature. This is a difficult case, and in general very little is known, except for a handful of special cases such as the unit balls of lpsuperscriptğ‘™ğ‘l^{p}-norm and some generalizations. For these cases, the effect of vanishing curvature on the error estimates has been extensively investigated, and we refer the reader to [16], [17], and [18].

The lattice point counting problem that we shall consider in the present paper will take a similar form to that of (1.1), the crucial difference being the dilation used in the expansion process. Our interest in this change of setting is motivated by viewing our lattice point counting problem in a wider context, as we now explain.

Counting points in lattice subgroups. In view of (1.1), it is natural to consider the following considerably more general set-up. Suppose ğ†âŠ‚ğ†ğ‹nğ†subscriptğ†ğ‹ğ‘›\mathbf{G}\subset\mathbf{GL}_{n} is a connected linear algebraic group defined over â„šâ„š\mathbb{Q} such that Î“=ğ†â€‹(â„¤)Î“ğ†â„¤\Gamma=\mathbf{G}(\mathbb{Z}), its collection of integral points, forms a lattice subgroup in the group G=ğ†â€‹(â„)âŠ‚ğ†ğ‹nâ€‹(â„)Gğ†â„subscriptğ†ğ‹ğ‘›â„\textit{G}=\mathbf{G}(\mathbb{R})\subset\mathbf{GL}_{n}(\mathbb{R}) of real points. Let â„¬tâŠ‚Gsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡G\mathcal{B}_{t}\subset\textit{G} be a family of bounded Borel subsets parameterized by tâˆˆâ„+ğ‘¡subscriptâ„t\in\mathbb{R}_{+} satisfying Î¼â€‹(â„¬t)â†’âˆâ†’ğœ‡subscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡\mu(\mathcal{B}_{t})\to\infty, where Î¼ğœ‡\mu denotes the Haar measure on G normalized so to have measure 111 on a fundamental domain of Î“Î“\Gamma in G. In analogy with the Euclidean case, one aims to establish an asymptotic estimate of the form

|Î“âˆ©â„¬t|=Î¼â€‹(â„¬t)+ğ’ªÏµâ€‹(Î¼â€‹(â„¬t))Îº+ÏµÎ“subscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡ğœ‡subscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡subscriptğ’ªitalic-Ïµsuperscriptğœ‡subscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡ğœ…italic-Ïµ|\Gamma\cap\mathcal{B}_{t}|=\mu(\mathcal{B}_{t})+\mathcal{O}_{\epsilon}(\mu(\mathcal{B}_{t}))^{\kappa+\epsilon} (1.2)

for any Ïµ>0italic-Ïµ0\epsilon>0, where Îºğœ…\kappa is taken to be the infimum over all admissible exponents.

There are numerous methods to construct interesting families â„¬tâŠ‚Gsubscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡G\mathcal{B}_{t}\subset\textit{G}. One such method, which is the one we shall adopt, is to consider a gauge Ï‰ğœ”\omega defined on G, i.e a left-invariant pseudo-distance function, and then take â„¬t={gâˆˆG:Ï‰â€‹(g,e)<t}subscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡conditional-setğ‘”Gğœ”ğ‘”ğ‘’ğ‘¡\mathcal{B}_{t}=\{g\in\textit{G}:\omega(g,e)<t\}. Of particular interest is the case where the gauge is taken to be a (proper) left-invariant distance function. In this direction, let us mention that (1.2) has never been established, even in a single case, for any left-invariant distance function on any non-compact simple Lie group. For more details, as well as for other interesting examples and related results on the error terms, we refer the reader to [8].

In the present paper we intend to establish (1.2) for the case of the first Heisenberg group, where the gauge is taken to be the Cygan-KoraÂ´Â´ğ‘\acute{a}nyi Heisenberg-norm. In fact, we shall first state the lattice point counting problem on an arbitrary Heisenberg group with respect to a certain family of gauges. This family, consisting of the so called Heisenberg-norms, arises naturally through the action of the dilation and unitary groups, and was considered in [7] where the reader may find an in-depth and broad treatment of the lattice point counting problem on the Heisenberg groups.

We now turn to describe the set-up for the lattice point counting problem considered in [7], and we shall do so in the context of (1.2). Thus, for the time being we consider an Heisenberg group of arbitrary dimension along with any Heisenberg norm defined on it.

1.3 Statement of results

Setting x=t4ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¡4x=t^{4}, the counting problem is that of estimating the sum

ğ’®â€‹(x)=âˆ‘0â‰¤m2+n2<xr2â€‹(m).ğ’®ğ‘¥subscript0superscriptğ‘š2superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘š\mathcal{S}(x)=\sum_{0\leq m^{2}+n^{2}<\,x}r_{2}(m)\,. (1.7)

We are now ready to state our main results.

Theorem 1.

With â„°â€‹(x)â„°ğ‘¥\mathcal{E}(x) as above, we have:

lim supxâ†’âˆâ„°â€‹(x)x12=âˆsubscriptlimit-supremumâ†’ğ‘¥â„°ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥12\limsup_{x\to\infty}\frac{\mathcal{E}(x)}{x^{\frac{1}{2}}}=\infty (1.9)
lim infxâ†’âˆâ„°â€‹(x)x12=âˆ’âˆsubscriptlimit-infimumâ†’ğ‘¥â„°ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥12\liminf_{x\to\infty}\frac{\mathcal{E}(x)}{x^{\frac{1}{2}}}=-\infty (1.10)

In [7], the upper-bound |â„°â€‹(x)|â‰ªx12â€‹logâ¡xmuch-less-thanâ„°ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥12ğ‘¥\left|\mathcal{E}(x)\right|\ll x^{\frac{1}{2}}\log{x} has been established, hence as an immediate corollary we deduce:

Corollary.

The exponent 1212\frac{1}{2} in the upper-bound |â„°â€‹(x)|â‰ªx12â€‹logâ¡xmuch-less-thanâ„°ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥12ğ‘¥\left|\mathcal{E}(x)\right|\ll x^{\frac{1}{2}}\log{x} obtained by Garg, Nevo & Taylor can not be improved and is thus best possible, thereby establishing (1.6) with the value of Îº=12ğœ…12\kappa=\frac{1}{2}.

On the method of proof. One may approach the sum ğ’®â€‹(x)ğ’®ğ‘¥\mathcal{S}(x) in several ways, one of which is by first replacing the sharp cutoff function Ï‡[0,x)subscriptğœ’0ğ‘¥\chi_{[0,x)} by an appropriately chosen smooth function of compact support, and then apply Poisson summation for the smoothed sum. The zero frequency gives rise to the main term, and one is left with estimating the tail. As we wish to retain the true order of magnitude of â„°â€‹(x)â„°ğ‘¥\mathcal{E}(x), we opt to choose a different approach as we now explain.

First we note that 2â€‹â„³â€‹(x)2â„³ğ‘¥2\mathcal{M}(x) differs from ğ’®â€‹(x)ğ’®ğ‘¥\mathcal{S}(x) by an amount of size at most ğ’ªâ€‹(x12)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘¥12\mathcal{O}(x^{\frac{1}{2}}), where

â„³â€‹(x)=âˆ‘0â‰¤mâ‰¤xr2â€‹(m)â€‹(xâˆ’m2)12.â„³ğ‘¥subscript0ğ‘šğ‘¥subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘š212\mathcal{M}(x)=\sum_{0\leq m\leq\,\sqrt[]{x}}r_{2}(m)(x-m^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}}\,. (1.11)

Thus, our theorem will follow if we can prove that the error term arising from the approximation of â„³â€‹(x)â„³ğ‘¥\mathcal{M}(x) obeys the two sided estimate Î©Â±â€‹(x12)subscriptÎ©plus-or-minussuperscriptğ‘¥12\Omega_{\pm}(x^{\frac{1}{2}}).

The presence of (xâˆ’m2)12superscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘š212(x-m^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}} in the above sum is more than welcome, as it serves as a smoothing factor. Already at this stage, by applying standard methods of contour integration one can establish the bound |â„°â€‹(x)|â‰ªx12â€‹(logâ¡x)Cmuch-less-thanâ„°ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¥12superscriptğ‘¥ğ¶\left|\mathcal{E}(x)\right|\ll x^{\frac{1}{2}}(\log{x})^{C} for some constant C>0ğ¶0C>0. By performing a more careful analysis, one could obtain a closed form expression for the error term arising in the estimation of (1.11), however it turns out to be difficult to extract any information as to its true order of magnitude. The reason behind this difficulty is that the variable of summation mğ‘šm appears in (xâˆ’m2)12superscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘š212(x-m^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}} with a squared factor. To see this more clearly, by Mellin inversion with Ïƒ>1ğœ1\sigma>1, we have

The Gamma factor in (1.12) does not match the one appearing in the functional equation for Zâ€‹(s)ğ‘ğ‘ Z(s), and this will cause some complications later on. To make the Gamma factors match, we first use Lemma 1 stated below to remove this square factor, and only then do we proceed to the evaluation of (1.12), leading us to the following sum

Concluding remarks. Our results remain valid in the case where the norm is taken to be ğ’©4,Asubscriptğ’©4ğ´\mathcal{N}_{4,A} for any A>0ğ´0A>0, as long as we consider this variable to be fixed. If we where to allow Ağ´A to vary with xğ‘¥x, then the question of uniformity comes into play, and it would be an interesting problem to consider. Likewise, one may consider the lattice point counting problem when one or both of the variables of summation are restricted by congruence conditions to various moduli which are allowed to vary with xğ‘¥x. It should be mentioned though, that the value of Î±=4ğ›¼4\alpha=4 was crucial to our arguments for obtaining the desired Î©Â±subscriptÎ©plus-or-minus\Omega_{\pm} estimates, while for different values we would have to settle for upper-bounds.

Let us now say a few words about higher dimensional Heisenberg groups, where the norm is still the Cygan-KoraÂ´Â´ğ‘\acute{a}nyi Heisenberg-norm. As in the case of â„‹1subscriptâ„‹1\mathcal{H}_{1}, the sum under consideration takes the form

ğ’®qâ€‹(x)=âˆ‘0â‰¤m2+n2<xr2â€‹qâ€‹(m)=âˆ‘l<xÏqâ€‹(l)subscriptğ’®ğ‘ğ‘¥subscript0superscriptğ‘š2superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘™ğ‘¥subscriptğœŒğ‘ğ‘™\mathcal{S}_{q}(x)=\sum_{0\leq m^{2}+n^{2}<\,x}r_{2q}(m)=\sum_{l<\,x}\rho_{q}(l)

where

Ïqâ€‹(l)=âˆ‘m2+n2=lr2â€‹qâ€‹(m).subscriptğœŒğ‘ğ‘™subscriptsuperscriptğ‘š2superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘™subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘ğ‘š\rho_{q}(l)=\sum_{m^{2}+n^{2}=l}r_{2q}(m)\,.

Now, for integers lğ‘™l such that r2â€‹(l)=0subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘™0r_{2}(l)=0 we have Ïqâ€‹(l)=0subscriptğœŒğ‘ğ‘™0\rho_{q}(l)=0 no matter what the value of qğ‘q is, and thus they do not make any contribution to the sum ğ’®qâ€‹(x)subscriptğ’®ğ‘ğ‘¥\mathcal{S}_{q}(x), while those for which r2â€‹(l)â‰ 0subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘™0r_{2}(l)\neq 0 will have a larger contribution as qğ‘q grows due to the presence of r2â€‹qâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘â‹…r_{2q}(\cdotp) in Ïqâ€‹(â‹…)subscriptğœŒğ‘â‹…\rho_{q}(\cdotp).
